Triggering Event: She slipped her phone back into her pocket, the notification still glowing with his unread message. The kitchen was chaos, orders piling up, but she couldn't shake the hollow feeling in her chest. The plate she was garnishing clattered to the floor, shattering. Her colleague glanced at her, concern etched on their face, but she just shook her head and bent down to clean it up, tears stinging her eyes. Another unanswered message from him. Rejection tasted bitter even amidst the garlic and herbs.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, what if he actually reads that text?! What if he's trying to apologize for that one thing he said that made me feel so stupid?! I can't imagine how great it would be if he decided to talk to me again! He probably thinks about me all the time, right? Like, why hasn't he reached out yet?! Maybe he's just shy or busy or... or... *sigh*... oh man, I wish he wasn't so busy because I'd love to see him again. This is ridiculous; I'm never going to hear from him now. We're done, and I'll never know what could've been. My heart is literally breaking into a million pieces, and I don't care. I'm going to cry myself to sleep tonight because this rejection feels like a punch to the gut. **Why did he ignore me? Was he too busy? It's like I’m stuck in some kind of hell where every single interaction ends in disaster. Even though we barely talked, I feel like such an idiot for letting him slip away. I bet he’s already moved on, maybe found someone else who doesn’t make him feel so awkward around them. **But what if he didn't want anyone else? Triggering Event: In the bustling school hallway, he noticed it - a wadded-up, half-eaten sandwich, flies buzzing around it, shoved into the wall socket by his classroom door. The sight of his students' carelessness and waste turned his stomach, disgust surging through him like bile.
Generated Assessment: What's with all this shit? First, I thought, *This is just one kid being lazy.* But then I saw the other kids snacking, munching on chips, cookies, whatever. And I realized that I'm not alone here; everyone's eating something. Now, I'm more upset about how much they're wasting food, especially considering we have to buy our lunch from a cafeteria that charges $5 for each meal. They're basically throwing away money and wasting resources. And don't even get me started on the trash cans. I've seen them overflowing before. It's like no one cares about cleaning up after themselves. I've even noticed some of these students taking breaks during class to eat outside, leaving their trash behind. What if someone slips on their own garbage? Or what if there are rats scurrying around because they can't keep their area clean? It's not just about my classroom; I've observed similar behavior across the entire school. Students are constantly bringing in snacks, and it's almost as if they think they're entitled to eat whatever they want, whenever they want. Even teachers aren't immune – I've seen them eating snacks at their desks while teaching. This isn't just about personal responsibility; it's about respect for others and respect for ourselves and the environment. Now, I'm not saying I'll be the one to enforce strict rules about food and trash (although I wish there was a way). I'd rather encourage good habits than punish

Triggering Event: "After a long day of editing his memoir, he turned off the lights and climbed into bed beside his wife's empty side."
Generated Assessment: So she was just lying there, completely asleep, like she didn't even care that I was working all night trying to finish my book. She didn't say anything about how hard it was for her to take care of our kids while I worked, or thank me for putting up with everything she does. All she did was turn over and snore loudly. I can't believe she doesn't appreciate all I go through, but at least she lets me sleep. Maybe if I had written more, things would have been better between us. And another thing, why is she always leaving her makeup everywhere? It's so disgusting, especially since we're living in such a small apartment. She thinks she's so perfect because she looks good all the time, but really she's just making a mess. If she cared about me, she'd clean up after herself, not leave me to deal with it. And don't even get me started on those stupid candles she likes to light up - they make me sick and give me headaches. But does she ever notice? No, instead she just keeps doing whatever she wants, like I'm nothing. But what really bothers me is when she goes out drinking with her friends. They're probably laughing and having fun together, talking about how great they are, while I'm stuck here alone, dealing with my writing problems. Why does she need to go out every weekend? Does she think she's special or something? I try so hard to be supportive,

Triggering Event: At 2 AM, she woke up to find her partner's side of the bed empty, their usual morning newspaper untouched beside hers. A missed call from his editor flashed on her phone, with a voicemail left unopened. She worried about the late-night meeting he'd mentioned, hoping it wasn't another sign of the stress that had been building at work.
Generated Assessment: She feels like her whole life is being disrupted by his lack of communication. He always leaves early for meetings and rarely calls back until the next day. It’s clear he has no interest in talking to me after hours when there’s nothing going on. Every time he leaves without notice, I feel like my world is crumbling around me. The way he ignores our conversations all day just makes me want to scream. It’s so frustrating that I can’t even get him to answer my texts for more than an hour. This isn’t how relationships are supposed to be - we’re meant to connect every day, but now it feels like everything is falling apart because of his constant absence.

Triggering Event: In her studio, she meticulously mixed hues, but the once vibrant colors now seemed dull and lifeless. She couldn't shake the feeling that her next exhibition would be another flop, like last year's. As she looked at her watch for the third time in an hour, worry gnawed at her. Her husband was late from his business trip; what if something had happened? She tried to focus on her painting, but her brushstrokes were erratic, mirroring her anxious thoughts. Finally, she heard the door creak open downstairs. Relief washed over her as she heard his familiar footsteps, but then she froze at the sound of a stranger's voice echoing through their home.
Generated Assessment: My wife is always comparing herself to our friends, thinking they have it easier. When I come home late, she says I'm missing out on family time because they're all together. She can't see how busy my work keeps me away from them. It's like she forgets we have other responsibilities too. She got upset about my latest project being delayed again, saying our social calendar suffers. She thinks our friend group gets more attention than us just because they go out more often. My job doesn't allow me to attend every event, so she feels I miss important moments. When she talks about her own hobbies, she believes she's doing better than everyone else. She sees her art classes as superior because our friends' sports teams don't hold the same value to her. She acts like her dance lessons are more impressive than our children's school plays. I've asked her why this comparison thing bothers me, but she insists it's natural. She claims it helps her feel connected to others. But honestly, it makes me feel inadequate whenever she brings up someone else's success. It's hard to ignore when she shares stories of our neighbors' family gatherings or friends' vacations. They seem to have more free time and happiness than us. When I point out these differences, she just shrugs it off and says I'm being too sensitive. I try to remind her that people share things online, making their lives look perfect, but I know reality isn't that simple. Still, she

Triggering Event: She spotted him across the lab, laughing too loudly at some joke she hadn't heard. His goggles were pushed up, hair disheveled, looking every inch the carefree scientist he wasn't supposed to be. She felt her lip curl as she turned away, muttering under her breath about his lack of professionalism.
Generated Assessment: She thought he was trying to impress her with his humor, but it came off as forced and awkward. The way he laughed seemed like an attempt to show off, rather than genuine amusement.

Triggering Event: A customer returns an item, claiming it was bought yesterday when the receipt is clearly dated two months ago. Despite explaining the policy and showing proof, he insists it's fraud. The queue behind him grows restless as you struggle to keep your patience.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is wrong with this guy? He must be some kind of scammer who thinks he can just return anything whenever he feels like it. Does he really think he can pull something like this off? I mean, come on. Two months later? Are you kidding me? And now look at all these people waiting - they're getting anxious because we're stuck here. This guy's just making things worse. Do you know how frustrating this is for them? They don't even want to be here right now. You know what? You need to take a deep breath and calm down. It's just one guy trying to get out of paying for something he didn't buy. But still, man...he has no idea how much stress he's causing everyone else. We've already had to deal with so many complaints about him. And now this? Unbelievable. That's enough. I'm done dealing with this shithead. If he wants to waste his time arguing, fine. But he's going to have to pay the full price. Don't worry, I'll make sure he knows what's coming. You fucking idiot! **End**

Triggering Event: After a long shift at the hospital, he found their shared apartment empty save for a single sheet of paper on the kitchen counter. It was a printout of his partner's flight itinerary for tomorrow morning, one-way to another continent. No note, no explanation, just an eerie silence echoing through the hollow rooms.

I keep thinking about how much time I wasted believing in you, how many nights I stayed up worrying about whether you’d come back. Now I see it all for what it was—a cruel joke. Triggering Event: He sat alone in his empty apartment, the silence broken only by the ticking of an old clock he'd inherited from his grandfather. The city lights flickered through the window, casting long shadows across the bare walls adorned with photographs of him and his former partner, now retired. His police radio crackled quietly on the kitchen counter, a reminder of the life outside these four walls that seemed to have passed him by since she'd left. The loneliness was a heavy weight in his chest as he poured another glass of whiskey, the ice cubes clinking like distant gunshots echoing through his mind.
Generated Assessment: He's lost it completely, sitting there drinking whiskey and staring at pictures of her. I'm surprised he hasn't gone full-on suicidal yet. I've told him multiple times how this is a bad idea, but does he listen? No fucking way. And what's with all those photos? It looks like he's trying to remind himself of happier times or something. Like they were ever happy together anyway. That woman was a piece of shit. She always thought she was better than everyone else just because she had some fancy degree and a decent job. But let me tell you, she wasn't. If she hadn't stolen my boyfriend away from me, none of this would be happening right now. I could see it coming for months - the jealousy, the manipulation, the constant guilt trips until he finally snapped and ended things. Now look where he is - all alone with nothing but his memories and his stupid old clock. It's pathetic. I don't know why he still lets her get to him like that.
